required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Integrating Caregiver Support Into MS Care
clinical_study.official_title: Integrating Caregiver Support Into MS Care

lead_sponsor.agency: VA Office of Research and Development

clinical_study.source: VA Office of Research and Development

brief_summary.textblock:
With loss of mobility in multiple sclerosis (MS) comes an increase in amount and types of caregiver assistance, with a concomitant increase in burden for the caregiver. In fact, effect on caregiver burden can be seen as a potential indicator of the efficacy of MS management, suggesting that the caregiver is an appropriate and independent target for MS therapeutic strategies.
MS patients report difficulty implementing and continuing with home exercise, mobility, and walking programs. This feasibility study will test integration of a successful behavioral caregiving intervention into clinical practice to improve functioning of Veterans with multiple sclerosis (MS) and their Caregivers. Caregivers of Veterans with MS will receive a behavioral caregiver intervention designed to address caregiver coping and management of patient concerns, with special focus on patient mobility and walking. A pre-post intervention design will compare outcomes for Veterans and Caregivers.
For Veterans, the intervention will target Caregiver participation in home-based Veteran mobility activities. MS Caregivers report high burden, stress, and depression involved in caring for their loved ones, especially as mobility declines and these outcomes are related to physical and emotional health status of the patient. For Caregivers, the intervention will focus on improving Caregiver coping and on managing MS-related problems. Outcomes for both will be measured at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months.
Study Objectives include:
- Test whether a caregiver intervention can be integrated into an MS clinical setting.
- Determine whether Caregiver outcomes are improved (depression, burden, anxiety, and number of Veteran MS problems and safety alerts reported).
- Determine whether Veteran outcomes are improved (Expanded Disability Status Scale, timed up and go test, self-efficacy, and depression).
- Determine which types of Caregivers will benefit most.
- Determine which types of Veterans will benefit most.
- Refine materials for future clinical research, translation and implementation.

primary_outcome.measure: Depression Measured With the Patient Health Questionnaire 9 (PHQ-9) Scale
primary_outcome.description: Caregiver primary outcome. PHQ-9, range 0-27, lower better

primary_outcome.measure: Burden Measured With the Zarit Burden Inventory
primary_outcome.description: Caregiver primary outcome. Zarit Burden Inventory, 12 item, 0-48, lower better

primary_outcome.measure: Anxiety Measured With the Generalized Anxiety Disorders 7 Scale
primary_outcome.description: Caregiver primary outcome. General Anxiety Disorders Scale - GAD-7, range 0-21, lower better
Caregiver primary outcome - number of possible troubling patient problems and concerns, range 0-27, lower better
Number of troubling patient problems or concerns that bother the caregiver, range 0-27, lower better

arm_group.description: Behavioral intervention with caregivers to reduce stress and management of patient concerns, particularly ambulation

intervention.description: Education and skills building, including problem solving, cognitive restructuring, and stress management

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Veteran being seen in MS clinic at Memphis VA
- Veteran ambulatory
- Caregiver/care partner who agrees to participate
Exclusion Criteria:
- None

overall_official.affiliation: Memphis VA Medical Center, Memphis, TN

facility.name: Memphis VA Medical Center, Memphis, TN

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Recruitment occurred in the Neurology Service at the Memphis Veterans Affairs Medical Center (VAMC).

Anxiety change from baseline to six months
measure.description: Caregiver, General Anxiety Disorders Scale-7, (GAD-7), range 0-21, lower better

measure.title: Depression change from baseline to six months
measure.description: Caregiver, Patient Health Questionnaire - 9, PHQ-9, range 0-27, lower better

measure.title: Burden change from baseline to six months
measure.description: Caregiver, Zarit Burden Inventory, 12 item, 0-48, lower better

measure.title: Caregiving tasks change from baseline to six months
measure.description: Caregiving Tasks in Multiple Sclerosis Scale (CTiMSS), range 0-96, lower better

measure.title: Social support change from baseline to six months
measure.description: Caregiver, received support, satisfaction, negative interactions, range 0-30, higher better

measure.title: Self Care change from baseline to six months
measure.description: Caregiver, health services use, range 0-14, higher is better

measure.title: Caregiving frustrations change from baseline to six months
measure.description: Feel like yelling or hitting, range 0-4, lower better

measure.title: Hours on duty change from baseline to six months
measure.description: Mahoney Vigilance Scale, number of hours caregiver feels on duty, range 0-24

measure.title: Hours performing tasks change from baseline to six months
measure.description: Mahoney Vigilance Scale, number of hours actually performing tasks, range 0-24

measure.title: Concerning care recipient behaviors change from baseline to six months
measure.description: Number of possible patient troubling behaviors or concerns, range, 0-27

measure.title: Number of behaviors that bother change from baseline to six months
measure.description: Number of possible patient troubling behaviors or concerns that bother the caregiver, range 0-27

measure.title: Timed Up and Go Test change from baseline to six months
measure.description: Care Recipient, Timed Up and Go Test (TUGT), seconds (for analysis - square root transformed seconds), fewer better

measure.title: MS Self-efficacy change from baseline to six months
measure.description: Care Recipient, Multiple Sclerosis Self-Efficacy Scale (MSSS), score 14-84, higher better

measure.title: Disability Scale change from baseline to six months
measure.description: Care Recipient, Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS),0-10, lower better. Categories are percentage with mild (0-2.5 points), moderate (3.0-5.0), and severe (> 6) disability.

measure.title: Depression change from baseline to six months
measure.description: Care Recipient, Patient Health Questionnaire - 9, PHQ-9, range 0-27, lower better

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
